case_vignette: a 5-year-old female presents with a plaque on her left leg. the lesion appeared a few months after her birth. it has been increasing in size proportionally to her growth. the parents mentions that the skin lesion sometimes becomes irritated, erythematous and itchy when the patient plays with it or when she gets sick. physical exam reveals a red-brown well delimited plaque on her left leg without any noticeable erythema or epidermal changes.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
The skin mark on my left leg sometimes gets red, irritated, and itchy, especially when I play with it or if I get sick.
How long have you had the skin mark on your leg?
I've had the skin mark on my leg since a few months after I was born.
Has the appearance of the skin mark changed over time?
Yes, the skin mark has been increasing in size as I grow.
Do you have any similar skin marks elsewhere on your body?
No, I only have the skin mark on my left leg.
Do you have any family history of skin conditions or cancers?
I'm sorry, I don't have that information.
Has the skin mark been evaluated by a healthcare professional before? If yes, what was their opinion?
Yes, it has been evaluated, and they noticed it's a well-defined red-brown plaque without any noticeable skin irritation or changes on the surface.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Melanocytic Nevus.
